results.title: Chemistry in nature
results.creator_credit: Educational Media Australia and Iwanami Film
results.brief_description: This film attempts to correct the view that chemistry only takes place in the laboratory. Two examples from Japan are used showing a volcanic lake found to be the most acidic in the world and the spectacular production of sulphur from gases emitted by volcanic vents. An explanation of the processes involved is demonstrated using laboratory equipment in the field. Discussion pauses are provided. Suitable for secondary level.
results.description: This film attempts to correct the view that chemistry only takes place in the laboratory. results.title: Don't be a bloody idiot!
results.creator_credit: Edwin Moses, Don Anderson, Tasmanian Film Corporation and Tasmania. Police Dept.
results.brief_description: What to do and what not to do when planning a trip into the Australian bush. Looks at safety and essential equipment. Suitable for upper secondary and tertiary levels.

results.title: High country children of New Zealand
results.creator_credit: Dave Gibson, Yvonne MacKay and Gibson Film Productions
results.brief_description: Two children - Malcolm and Nerelli Prouting - live with their family on a sheep station in the isolated high country of south New Zealand. This film shows their daily lives from the excitement of mustering high up in the hills to mundane correspondence school work. Filmed on location at Mount Arrowsmith Station, New Zealand.

results.title: Jubilee and beyond
results.creator_credit: Ivan Gaal, Ross Campbell and Victoria. Audio-Visual Education Centre
results.brief_description: A non-narrated impression of the Royal visit to Melbourne, in the Queen’s Jubilee year, in 1977. Showing behind the scene preparations by the Army and Navy personnel, news crews, teachers and school children. The actual event is intercut with students from McRobertson Girls High School and Melbourne High School conducting a debate about the role of the Monarchy in Australia, touching on the issue of republic as an alternative. A good discussion starter on a ‘hot’ issue. (Includes shot of the half-built Westgate Bridge and Melbourne city skyline).
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ivan Gaal, Ross Campbell and Victoria. Audio-Visual Education Centre

results.title: The Cemetery of the elephants
results.creator_credit: Armando Robles Godoy, Mario Vasquez, Films Incorporated and Producciones Cinematograficas Nacionales
results.brief_description: An allegorical story about a young writer who leaves home with his manuscript determined to conquer the world, then returns home after years of struggle as an old man with the world still unconquered. Non-narrated. Suitable for middle secondary level.

results.title: Timor: island of fear, island of hope
results.creator_credit: Boubaker Adjala and Timor Defence Foundation
results.brief_description: An historical introduction to East Timor as well as a commentary on contemporary political and military conflicts. Includes film reports from four Australian journalists killed at Balibo in October 1975 and footage of Australian Labor MHR Ken Fry at the United Nations.

results.title: The Son of the Sheik. - [Edited version]
results.creator_credit: Saul J. Turell, Paul Killiam and Gregstan Enterprises
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “History of the Motion Picture”.
Presents an edited version of the 1926 production of “The Son of the Sheik”, a typical adventure of the golden age of the movies. Stars Rudolph Valentino. Narrated by Paul Killiam.

results.title: Mammals and milk
results.brief_description: Shows that mammals are all alike in the respect that they produce milk to feed their young. Also useful in early sex education and to stimulate language arts discussion. Suitable for upper primary level.
